Award.AwardTitle: Dynamics of the Antarctic Seasonal Ice Zone
Award.AbstractNarration:
The seasonal sea ice zone (SIZ) on the southern flank of the Antarctic Circumpolar Current is the region in which sea ice undergoes a massive seasonal cycle in its thickness and extent. The SIZ extends all the way around Antarctica and it is here that sea-ice manufacture and export leads to brine rejection and loss of buoyancy in the water column. In this way cold surface waters are preconditioned for subsequent convection, mixing and entrainment in coastal polynyas, under ice shelves and over the continental slope of Antarctica. The transformed (densified) waters ultimately make up Antarctic Bottom Water feeding the lower cell of the Southern Ocean (SO), connecting to the abyssal oceans. Despite the importance of the SIZ in driving the meridional circulation of the ocean-atmosphere climate system, its dynamics is not well observed, modeled or understood. This study seeks to model the fluid dynamics of the seasonal cycle of sea-ice formation in a strongly eddying region next to the continental shelf.

The broad impacts of the research center upon the Antarctic being a system of such great importance to global ocean circulation, and to climate. The study intends to bring together theory, observations and models to address the contemporary problem of uptake of heat to the abyssal ocean, and will provide a challenging context for the education of graduate students and postdoctoral researchers in interdisciplinary science. The development of MITgcm, an open source ocean model used by many, will also continue.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This was a proposal to study the dynamics of the seasonal sea ice zone (SIZ) on the poleward flank of the Antarctic Circumpolar Current of the Southern Ocean (SO) in which sea ice undergoes a massive seasonal cycle in its thickness and extent. The SIZ extends all the way around Antarctica and it is here that sea-ice manufacture and export leads to brine rejection and loss of buoyancy in the water column. In this way surface waters are preconditioned for subsequent convection, mixing and entrainment in coastal polynyas, under ice shelves and the continental slope of Antarctica. The transformed waters ultimately make up Antarctic Bottom Water feeding the lower cell of the SO. Despite the importance of the SIZ in the climate system it is not well observed, modeled, or understood.

 

A key observational result of the project was that we discovered how zonal wind anomalies modulate the SIZ. Following a summertime period of enhanced winds, the surface of the ocean cools, promoting sea ice growth in the Autumn. However, the following the winter, sea ice extent is diminished relative to the climatological seasonal cycle. We (i) proposed a mechanism to account for these observations involving the sequestration of heat in to the ocean in the summer/autumn and its warming of the mixed layer and consequent sea ice decline in the winter and (ii) demonstrated the mechanism at work in a hierarchy of models.

 

The significance of the research is that models, and in particular coupled climate models, have significant biases in the SIZ of the SO which compromise their fidelity for use in climate change projections. Our hope is that by testing them against the seasonal cycle of mixing and ice cover which have been highlighted, explored and documented in the project, the representation of the seasonal cycle in the models can be improved and thence the fidelity of climate change projections based on them will also be improved.

 

The research supported a graduate student who successfully completed their Ph.D. and a postdoctoral researcher who has now taken up a faculty position.
